bioghist.p: Art historian William Innes Homer is H. Rodney Sharp Professor Emeritus of Art History at the University of Delaware. His research includes work on American painters Albert Pinkham Ryder and Thomas Eakins, and Photo Secessionists Alfred Stieglitz, Gertrude Käsebier, Clarence White, and others.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of William Innes Homer, which document Homer’s research on art, design and photography in the early decades of the twentieth century. Materials in the collection include correspondence, research notes, slides, programs, and a copy of Homer’s Portrait of My Life: a Work in Progress. Artists and movements represented include Clarence S. White, Gertrude Käsebier, Alfred Stieglitz and the Photo Secessionists, Albert Pinkham Ryder, John Sloan, Chagall, Dufy, Leger, and Beaux Arts architects. Notable items in the collection include: a 1914 publisher's prospectus from Galerie Vollard for work by Paul Cezanne; a 1913 prospectus for the Albert and Charles Boni magazine The Glebe; a brochure, with commentary by Gertrude Traubel, for a 1919 painting and sculpture exhibition at the Macdowell Club in New York; and a small collection of books and periodicals related to the history and technology of photography.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
